lesson.title: Phase 4: Decide
lesson.summary: This lesson covers the fourth phase of the Design Sprint -- Deciding. We'll get an overview of this phase and learn methods to narrow down and converge on one idea.

atoms.title: DECIDE Heading
atoms.text: ## Phase 4: Decide

atoms.title: DECIDE Image
atoms.caption: Phase 4 of the Design Sprint: Decide
atoms.alt: Decide is phase 4 of the Design Sprint

atoms.title: Summary
atoms.text: Lots of ideas! And it’s now time to pick the best one. We’ll cover a couple different ways that you can start to converge on a single idea to prototype and test.

atoms.title: Topics & Learning Objectives
atoms.text:
## Topics and Learning Objectives  
In this lesson, we’ll cover the following topics:
- The Decide phase of the Design Sprint
- Assumptions & Questions
- Decision Matrix
- Thinking Hats

At the end of this lesson, you’ll be able to:
- Describe the Decide phase of the Design Sprint
- Articulate assumptions behind ideas and question them
- Create a Decision Matrix
- Represent perspectives from a wider audience

atoms.title: Glossary
atoms.text:
## Glossary  

Here are some of the terms we will be covering in this lesson:
  
| Term | Definition |
| ----------- | ----------- |
| Decision Matrix | A method to visualize the trade offs between different ideas  |
| Thinking Hats | A method to ensure that different perspectives are being discussed |

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Heading
atoms.text: ## Assumptions & Questions

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Recap
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember
- Questioning assumptions is a good way to make sure that you don’t get stuck in a specific way of thinking
- It’s easiest to start by identifying assumptions, and then drilling down and asking questions to see if those assumptions still stand

question.prompt: True or false:Questioning assumptions will always lead to alternative, innovative ideas.

question.title: Assumption
question.text: Think about [Spectacles by Snapchat](https://www.spectacles.com/ ) (sunglasses with a camera and Snapchat integration). Write an assumption that the product made

answer.text: Thanks for your response. Good examples could include assumptions related to privacy, for example, “People don’t mind being recorded”

question.title: Question
question.text: Now turn that assumption into a question

answer.text: Thanks for your response. A good question should challenge the assumption from the previous quiz, for example “Are bystanders comfortable with their image being captured without their knowledge” or “Will people interact or feel different when talking to someone who is wearing a camera on their face?”

atoms.title: Exercise: Grocery Store Chain Assumptions and Questions
atoms.text:
## Exercise: Grocery Store Chain App Assumptions and Questions

Let's take a closer look at your Grocery Store Chain product Solution Sketch -- or you can look at my Autopilot Solution Sketch below.What assumptions did you make?  How can you turn those assumptions into questions?

atoms.title: Grocery Store Chain product Sketch Assumptions

question.title: List the assumptions here.
question.text: Look carefully at the Autopilot Sketch. What assumptions does it make?

answer.text: Thanks for your response.  You can see my assumptions in the video below

question.title: List the questions here. You can see my questions in the video below.
question.text: Re-write the assumptions you identified above as questions

atoms.title: Click Next
atoms.text: Click **Next** to see my solution

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Example header
atoms.text:
## Solution: Grocery Store Chain App Assumptions and Questions  

Here are my assumptions and questions  about the Grocery Store Chain app.

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Example Summary
atoms.text:
| Assumptions | Questions | | ----------- | ----------- | | Consumers buy the same items | Do consumers buy the same items?

Are there factors that affect item choice (ie: will some people just buy what’s cheapest) | | Consumers buy some items on a regular cadence | What factors affect how often consumers purchase an item? | | Consumers are comfortable with a set it and forget it type of subscription for some types of goods | Are consumers comfortable with a subscription?

What types of goods would consumers be comfortable subscribing to? |

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Summary
atoms.text: Questioning assumptions is a good way to make sure that you are exploring all angles of a solution

atoms.title: Assumptions & Questions Further Research
atoms.text:
## Assumptions & Questions Further Research   


* [Don’t Make Me Think – Key Learning Points for UX Design for the Web](https://www.interaction-design.org/literature/article/don-t-make-me-think-key-learning-points-for-ux-design-for-the-web)

* [Assumption Busting](http://creatingminds.org/tools/assumption_busting.htm)

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Heading
atoms.text: ## Decision Matrix

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Example
atoms.caption: Decision Matrix
atoms.alt: Decision Matrix allows you to rank ideas across user value and effort

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Recap
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember
A decision matrix allows you to visualize the trade offs between different ideas when comparing across two criteria.
- Ideas generally worth pursuing will be high value & low effort or high value & high effort
- Ideas that are low value & high effort are generally not worth pursuing unless value increases or effort decreases in the future - Ideas that may not make sense to pursue now, may be worth pursuing later if the value of the idea increase or the effort to pursue the idea decreases

question.prompt: Which of the following ideas are worth pursuing

atoms.title: Decision Matrix for quizzes
atoms.caption: Use this Decision Matrix for the quizzes below

atoms.title: Decision Matrix - Best Idea to Move Forward

question.prompt: Which of the following ideas is the best one to move forward with in the Design Sprint?

atoms.title: Quiz  set up
atoms.text:
## Decision Matrix Practice

In the next two quizzes we will consider four different product ideas.  
* A feature that screens calls from suspected scammers
* An app that alerts you when your shoelaces are untied
* A feature that allows you to unsend an email up to one minute after you sent it.
* An app that lets you play10 different animal sounds

complex_prompt.text: How would you categorize the four product ideas?

concepts.text: A feature that screens calls from suspected scammers
An app that alerts you when your shoelaces are untied
A feature that allows you to unsend an email up to one minute after you sent it.
An app that lets you play 10 different animal sounds

atoms.title: Which idea should the team pursue?

question.title: Which idea should the team pursue?
question.text: Which of these four ideas should the team pursue?  Why?

answer.text:
Thanks for your response. There are two ideas that I’d recommend the team look into...

The first is the unsend idea. Have you ever wanted to unsend an email right you sent it because you noticed a typo or remembered something else you wanted to include? I know I have… There’s a lot of value in this feature and likely you could use a simple timer to delay sending so that users have a chance to “unsend”.

The second is the call screening idea. Spam calls are a huge annoyance! Screening spam calls is a hard problem to solve but there’s a ton of user value if it can figure out how to do it right.

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Example header
atoms.text:
## Exercise: Grocery Store Decision Matrix  
Let's apply the Decision Matrix tool to the Grocery Store ideas.  You can use your own ideas, use my ideas from the Crazy 8's sketches below, or come up with some completely new ideas.

atoms.title: Crazy 8's sketches
atoms.caption: A few ideas for the Grocery Store

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Task List
tasks: Create a 2 by 2 Decision Matrix table
Pick 3 ideas for the Grocery Store Chain  app and write each on a sticky note.
On each sticky add a short explanation of the value and an estimate of the effort including rationale
Place each idea in a quadrant
Circle the ideas that are worth pursuing
atoms.positive_feedback: Good job! See the next page to see how I did the Decision Matrix for the Grocery Store app.
atoms.description: Create a Decision Matrix to explore ideas for the Grocery Store Chain app

atoms.title: Click next
atoms.text: Click **Next** to see my solution

atoms.title: Solution: Decision Matrix
atoms.text:
## Solution: Grocery Store Chain App Decision Matrix  
Here is how I completed the Grocery Store Chain Decision Matrix.

atoms.title: Apps for the Decision Matrix
atoms.caption: Some of my Grocery Store ideas
atoms.alt: Some of my Grocery Store ideas

atoms.title: Grocery Store Decision Matrix Solution
atoms.caption: My Decision Matrix for the Grocery Store Chain app

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Example Summary
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember  
A decision matrix is a visual tool that allows you to sort and compare things across a set of criteria. 
- Draw a matrix on a white board and label your axes
- Write each idea onto a sticky note
- For each idea, have a short discussion on which is the appropriate quadrant
- Then place the sticky note into the appropriate quadrant

atoms.title: Decision Matrix Further Research
atoms.text:
## Decision Matrix Further Research   


* [Decision Matrix](https://designsprintkit.withgoogle.com/methodology/phase4-decide/decision-matrix)

atoms.title: Thinking Hats Heading
atoms.text: ## Thinking Hats

atoms.title: Thinking Hats Video recap
atoms.text:
## Things to Remember
The Thinking Hats exercise allows you to make sure that different perspectives are being discussed and pushes people to be open to different perspectives since everyone will have to represent multiple, differing views..  

The team discussion focuses on one hat at a time.  The order can vary, but you'll want to start and end with the blue hat (process). This order works well when comparing ideas:

* Blue hat - process (align on goals and order of hats)
* White hat - data  
* Green hat - creativity  
* Yellow hat - benefits  
* Black hat - judgment   
* Red hat - intuition
* Blue hat - process (summary of discussion)

question.prompt: True or false: You must wear a hat that matches your own view

atoms.title: Exercise: Grocery Store Chain Thinking Hats
atoms.text:
##  Exercise:  Grocery Store Chain App Thinking Hats

In this exercise we are going to look at some of our ideas for the Grocery Store using different hats.  Pick one of these ideas -- or use one of your own.

atoms.title: Autopilot Idea
atoms.caption: Think about this sketch as you wear each Thinking Hat.

question.title: Blue hat represents process
question.text: Put on the blue hat. How would you structure the conversation? What are the goals?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: White hat represents data
question.text: Now put on the white hat. What do we know? What do we need to find out?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: Green hat represents creativity
question.text: Now put on the green hat. What are new views? Or some alternative solutions?

answer.text: Thanks for your response.  See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: Yellow hat represents benefits
question.text: Now put on the yellow hat. For each idea, what are the benefits? How would you advocate for each one?

answer.text: Thanks for your response.  See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: Black hat represents judgment
question.text: Now put on the black hat. For each idea what are the challenges or things that could go wrong?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: Red hat represents intuition
question.text: Now put on the red hat. How are you feeling about each idea?

answer.text: Thanks for your response. See my thoughts in the next video.

question.title: Process
question.text: Now put on the blue hat back on. How would you summarize the overall conversation and viewpoints discussed? Which idea makes the most sense to pursue

atoms.title: Solution: Grocery Store app Thinking Hats
atoms.text:
## Solution: Grocery Store Chain App Thinking Hats  

Here's my take on the Grocery Store Chain app idea wearing the four Thinking Hats.

atoms.title: L5 07 Solution Grocery Store Chain Product Thinking Hats Part 1
Solution recap - process and data
atoms.text:
## Blue Hat - Process  
*  What goal do we want to pursue?
*  What sequence for the hats?  

## White Hat - Data  
We know:
* Consumers visit grocery stores ~1.6x week
* The average consumer spends 30 minutes in our store each visit (not including travel time) and purchases 13 items
* Our stores each carry around 50k items

atoms.title: L5 07 Solution Grocery Store Chain Product Thinking Hats Part 2
Thinking Hats Solution - Green and Yellow
atoms.text:
## Green Hat - Creativity  
* Digital vs. in store experiences
* What should the interaction of purchasing an item look like?

## Yellow Hat - Benefits
***Navigate:***  
* Makes it super easy to find items in the store
* High tech factor
* Similar to getting driving directions  

***Suggestions:***  
* Can be super helpful to surface products consumers will enjoy
* Helps if consumers forgot a specific product
* Super simple and lightweight interaction  

***Autopilot***
* Removes the need for consumers to create/manage shopping lists
* Options for store pick up or delivery
* Flexible re-ordering that has the potential to be based on purchase data

atoms.title: L5 07 Solution Grocery Store Chain Product Thinking Hats Part 3
Thinking Hats Recap
atoms.text:
## Black Hat - Judgment   
***Navigate:***  
* Really hard to do well 
* Overkill
* Many people won’t want to have an app open in order to navigate through a store   

***Suggestions:***  
* This would really only work for online purchases
* Do we have enough data to build this in a meaningful way?  

***Autopilot***
* Are consumers comfortable giving up this much control?
* What if pricing increases for an item? But the item is still auto-purchased?
* Giving choices between schedules and pick up/delivery creates additional complexity  

## Red Hat - Intuition  
* Navigation seems cool, but not sure we could execute on this with high quality
* Suggestions makes sense and seems like there’s little downside
* Autopilot seems the most exciting and has the opportunity to transform our business  

## Blue Hat - Process  
*  Move forward with Autopilot!    


Thinking hats is a method that allows you to make sure other perspectives are being represented and discussed when deciding on which idea to move forward to prototyping

atoms.title: Thinking Hats Further Research
atoms.text:
## Thinking Hats Further Research  
* [Six Thinking Hats](http://www.debonogroup.com/six_thinking_hats.php)
* [Six Hats of Critical Thinking](https://www.designorate.com/the-six-hats-of-critical-thinking-and-how-to-use-them/)

atoms.title: Header Text
atoms.text: # Lesson Recap

atoms.title: Lesson Recap
atoms.text:
You’ve reached the end of the Phase 4: Decide. We covered the following topics:
- The Decide phase of the Design Sprint
- Assumptions & Questions
- Decision Matrix
- Thinking Hats

At this point, you should be able to:
- Describe the Decide phase of the Sketch Sprint
- Identify and questions assumptions behind an idea
- Create a decision matrix to understand tradeoffs between multiple ideas
- Use Thinking Hats to make sure that diverse views are represented when discussing an idea
